segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Association Endpoint (AEP) services provide a programming contract for services that a device supports over a given protocol.
segment.target: Association Endpoint (AEP) services provide a programming contract for services that a device supports over a given protocol.

segment.source: Several of these services have established identifiers that should be used when referencing them.
segment.target: Several of these services have established identifiers that should be used when referencing them.

segment.source: These contracts are identified with the System.Devices.AepService.ServiceClassId property.
segment.target: These contracts are identified with the System.Devices.AepService.ServiceClassId property.

segment.source: This topic lists several well-known AEP service class IDs.
segment.target: This topic lists several well-known AEP service class IDs.

segment.source: The AEP service class ID is also applicable to protocols with custom class IDs.
segment.target: The AEP service class ID is also applicable to protocols with custom class IDs.

segment.source: An app developer should use advanced query syntax (AQS) filters based on the class IDs to limit their queries to the AEP services they plan to use.
segment.target: An app developer should use advanced query syntax (AQS) filters based on the class IDs to limit their queries to the AEP services they plan to use.

segment.source: This will both limit the query results to the relevant services and will significantly increase the performance, battery life, and quality of service for the device.
segment.target: This will both limit the query results to the relevant services and will significantly increase the performance, battery life, and quality of service for the device.

segment.source: For example, an application can use these service class IDs to use a device as a Miracast sync or DLNA digital media renderer (DMR).
segment.target: For example, an application can use these service class IDs to use a device as a Miracast sync or DLNA digital media renderer (DMR).

segment.source: For more information about how devices and services interact with each other, see **DeviceInformationKind**.
segment.target: For more information about how devices and services interact with each other, see **DeviceInformationKind**.

segment.source: Bluetooth services fall under one of two protocols, either the Bluetooth protocol or the Bluetooth LE protocol.
segment.target: Bluetooth services fall under one of two protocols, either the Bluetooth protocol or the Bluetooth LE protocol.

segment.source: The identifiers for these protocols are:
segment.target: The identifiers for these protocols are:

segment.source: The Bluetooth protocol supports several services, all following the same basic format.
segment.target: The Bluetooth protocol supports several services, all following the same basic format.

segment.source: The first four digits of the GUID vary based upon the service, but all Bluetooth GUIDs end with 0000-0000-1000-8000-00805F9B34FB.
segment.target: The first four digits of the GUID vary based upon the service, but all Bluetooth GUIDs end with 0000-0000-1000-8000-00805F9B34FB.

segment.source: For example, the RFCOMM service has the precursor of 0x0003, so the full ID would be 00030000-0000-1000-8000-00805F9B34FB.
segment.target: For example, the RFCOMM service has the precursor of 0x0003, so the full ID would be 00030000-0000-1000-8000-00805F9B34FB.

segment.source: The following table lists some common Bluetooth services.
segment.target: The following table lists some common Bluetooth services.

segment.source: For a more complete listing of available Bluetooth services, see Bluetooth's protocol and service pages here and here.
segment.target: For a more complete listing of available Bluetooth services, see Bluetooth's protocol and service pages here and here.

segment.source: You can also use the **GattServiceUuids** API to get some common GATT services.
segment.target: You can also use the **GattServiceUuids** API to get some common GATT services.

segment.source: Custom Bluetooth LE services use the following protocol identifier: {bb7bb05e-5972-42b5-94fc76eaa7084d49}
segment.target: Custom Bluetooth LE services use the following protocol identifier: {bb7bb05e-5972-42b5-94fc76eaa7084d49}

segment.source: Custom profiles are defined with their own defined GUIDs.
segment.target: Custom profiles are defined with their own defined GUIDs.

segment.source: This custom GUID should be used for System.Devices.AepService.ServiceClassId.
segment.target: This custom GUID should be used for System.Devices.AepService.ServiceClassId.

segment.source: UPnP services use the following protocol identifier: {0e261de4-12f0-46e6-91ba428607ccef64}
segment.target: UPnP services use the following protocol identifier: {0e261de4-12f0-46e6-91ba428607ccef64}

segment.source: In general, all UPnP services have their name hashed into a GUID using the algorithm defined in RFC 4122.
segment.target: In general, all UPnP services have their name hashed into a GUID using the algorithm defined in RFC 4122.

segment.source: The following table lists some common UPnP services defined in Windows.
segment.target: The following table lists some common UPnP services defined in Windows.

segment.source: WSD services use the following protocol identifier: {782232aa-a2f9-4993-971baedc551346b0}
segment.target: WSD services use the following protocol identifier: {782232aa-a2f9-4993-971baedc551346b0}

segment.source: In general, all WSD services have their name hashed into a GUID using the algorithm defined in RFC 4122.
segment.target: In general, all WSD services have their name hashed into a GUID using the algorithm defined in RFC 4122.

segment.source: The following table lists some common WSD services defined in Windows.
segment.target: The following table lists some common WSD services defined in Windows.

segment.source: This AQS will filter for all UPnP AssociationEndpointService objects that support DIAL.
segment.target: This AQS will filter for all UPnP AssociationEndpointService objects that support DIAL.

segment.source: In this case, **DeviceInformationKind** is set to AsssociationEndpointService.
segment.target: In this case, **DeviceInformationKind** is set to AsssociationEndpointService.
